Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.auth

Interface Realm

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BasicRealm, LDAPRealm, OAuthRealm
    public interface Realm
    A realm is a collection of authenticatable principals. These principals have passwords, and may be organised into groups or roles.

    Realm implementations declare which SASL mechanisms they support via getSupportedSASLMechanisms(). Servers should query this method and only advertise mechanisms that the configured realm supports.

    SelectorLoop Affinity

    Some realm implementations (e.g., LDAP) need to make client connections to perform authentication. To ensure these connections share affinity with the server's event loop, use forSelectorLoop(SelectorLoop) to obtain a realm instance bound to a specific loop:

    
 // In server initialization
 Realm configuredRealm = ...;
 Realm boundRealm = configuredRealm.forSelectorLoop(selectorLoop);
 server.setRealm(boundRealm);

    For simple synchronous realms like BasicRealm, this method simply returns this. For async realms, it returns a new instance with a client connection bound to the specified loop.

    Author:
    Chris Burdess
    See Also:
    SASLMechanism

    • Method Detail

      • forSelectorLoop

        Realm forSelectorLoop​(SelectorLoop loop)
        Returns a Realm instance bound to the specified SelectorLoop.

        This method allows realm implementations that need to make client connections (e.g., LDAP, database) to share the same event loop as the server using them. This ensures proper thread affinity and efficient I/O multiplexing.

        For synchronous realms that don't require client connections (like BasicRealm), this method should simply return this.

        For async realms, this method should return a new (or pooled) instance with a client connection bound to the specified loop. The returned realm may be a lightweight wrapper that shares configuration with the original but has its own connection state.

        Parameters:
        loop - the SelectorLoop to bind to
        Returns:
        a realm instance bound to the specified loop

      • getSupportedSASLMechanisms

        java.util.Set<SASLMechanism> getSupportedSASLMechanisms()
        Returns the set of SASL mechanisms this realm supports.

        Servers should call this method when building their capability response (e.g., IMAP CAPABILITY, SMTP EHLO AUTH, POP3 CAPA SASL) and only advertise mechanisms that the realm supports.

        The relationship between mechanisms and realm methods:

        • SASLMechanism.PLAIN, SASLMechanism.LOGIN - require passwordMatch(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.CRAM_MD5 - requires getCramMD5Response(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.DIGEST_MD5 - requires getDigestHA1(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.SCRAM_SHA_256 - requires getScramCredentials(java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.EXTERNAL - requires userExists(java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.OAUTHBEARER - requires validateBearerToken(java.lang.String)
        Returns:
        an unmodifiable set of supported SASL mechanisms

      • passwordMatch

        boolean passwordMatch​(java.lang.String username,
                      java.lang.String password)
        Verifies that the given password matches the stored credentials for the user. This is the preferred authentication method as it allows realm implementations to use password hashing without exposing plaintext passwords.
        Parameters:
        username - the username to authenticate
        password - the password to verify
        Returns:
        true if the password matches, false if the password is incorrect or user doesn't exist

      • getDigestHA1

        java.lang.String getDigestHA1​(java.lang.String username,
                              java.lang.String realmName)
        Computes the H(A1) hash for HTTP Digest Authentication (RFC 2617). H(A1) = MD5(username:realm:password) This allows realm implementations to either: - Store plaintext passwords and compute H(A1) on demand - Pre-compute and store H(A1) hashes directly (more secure)
        Parameters:
        username - the username
        realmName - the realm name used in the digest computation
        Returns:
        the H(A1) hash as a lowercase hex string, or null if user doesn't exist

      • getPassword

        @Deprecated
java.lang.String getPassword​(java.lang.String username)
                      throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Deprecated.
        This method exposes plaintext passwords and should be avoided. Use passwordMatch(String, String) for simple authentication or getDigestHA1(String, String) for HTTP Digest Authentication.
        Returns the password for the given user, or null if the user does not exist.
        Parameters:
        username - the username
        Returns:
        the plaintext password, or null if the user does not exist
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this realm only supports hashed passwords

      • isUserInRole

        boolean isUserInRole​(java.lang.String username,
                     java.lang.String role)
        Indicates whether the specified user has the given role.

        This is a standard security concept used for authorization decisions. Role names are defined by the application (e.g., "admin", "user", "ftp-read", "ftp-write").

        Parameters:
        username - the username to check
        role - the role name to check for
        Returns:
        true if the user has the specified role, false otherwise

      • userExists

        default boolean userExists​(java.lang.String username)
        Checks whether a user exists in this realm. This is useful for authentication mechanisms that need to verify user existence without checking a password (e.g., certificate-based auth).
        Parameters:
        username - the username to check
        Returns:
        true if the user exists, false otherwise

      • getCramMD5Response

        default java.lang.String getCramMD5Response​(java.lang.String username,
                                            java.lang.String challenge)
        Computes the expected CRAM-MD5 response for a user. CRAM-MD5 uses HMAC-MD5(password, challenge) where password is the key.

        Implementing this method allows realm implementations to support CRAM-MD5 authentication without exposing the plaintext password.

        Parameters:
        username - the username
        challenge - the server's challenge string
        Returns:
        the expected HMAC-MD5 digest as lowercase hex, or null if user doesn't exist
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this realm cannot compute CRAM-MD5 responses

      • getApopResponse

        default java.lang.String getApopResponse​(java.lang.String username,
                                         java.lang.String timestamp)
        Computes the expected APOP response for a user. APOP uses MD5(timestamp + password).

        Implementing this method allows realm implementations to support APOP authentication without exposing the plaintext password.

        Parameters:
        username - the username
        timestamp - the server's APOP timestamp (e.g., "<1234.5678@hostname>")
        Returns:
        the expected MD5 digest as lowercase hex, or null if user doesn't exist
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this realm cannot compute APOP responses

      • getScramCredentials

        default Realm.ScramCredentials getScramCredentials​(java.lang.String username)
        Gets the SCRAM credentials for a user.

        SCRAM (RFC 5802) uses derived keys instead of storing plaintext passwords:

        • SaltedPassword = PBKDF2(password, salt, iterations)
        • ClientKey = HMAC(SaltedPassword, "Client Key")
        • StoredKey = H(ClientKey)
        • ServerKey = HMAC(SaltedPassword, "Server Key")

        The realm stores StoredKey and ServerKey, never the password.

        Parameters:
        username - the username
        Returns:
        the SCRAM credentials, or null if user doesn't exist
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this realm doesn't support SCRAM

      • validateBearerToken

        default Realm.TokenValidationResult validateBearerToken​(java.lang.String token)
        Validates a Bearer token and returns the associated principal information. This method is used for Bearer Token Authentication (RFC 6750).
        Parameters:
        token - the bearer token to validate
        Returns:
        a TokenValidationResult containing the username, scopes, and validity, or null if token is invalid

      • validateOAuthToken

        default Realm.TokenValidationResult validateOAuthToken​(java.lang.String accessToken)
        Validates an OAuth access token and returns the associated principal information. This method is used for OAuth 2.0 Authentication (RFC 6749).
        Parameters:
        accessToken - the OAuth access token to validate
        Returns:
        a TokenValidationResult containing the username, scopes, and validity, or null if token is invalid
